profileText: A Senator from Michigan; born in North Weymouth, Mass., October 4, 1894; attended the public schools in Weymouth and Fore River Apprentice School in Quincy, Mass.; moved to Detroit, Mich., in 1921, and became active in union and civic affairs; engaged in the construction industry 1921-1955; director, Detroit area of Office of Price Administration, Rent Division 1942-1945; vice president of Stanley-Carter Co., Detroit, Mich., 1946-1954; member, Detroit City Council 1946-1947, and the Detroit Board of Education 1949-1955; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1954; reelected in 1960, and served from January 3, 1955, until his death in Bethesda, Md., April 30, 1966; chairman, Special Committee on Aging (Eighty-seventh Congress), Committee on Public Works (Eighty-eighth and Eighty-ninth Congresses); interment in Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Detroit, Mich.

McNamara, Late a Senator from Michigan. 89th Cong., 2d sess., 1966. Washington: Government Printing Office, 1967.

Cleary papers, 1944-1957; Ferdinand Northrup Menefee papers, 1928-1968; and Josephine Fellows Gomon papers, 1913-1971. Finding aid.
In Louis E. Shecter miscellaneous manuscripts, 1965, consisting of one-sentence appraisals of Kennedy's life and presidency.

1942-1966. 427.5 feet and 500 volumes. Chiefly senatorial papers including subject files (1955-1966), legislative files (1955-1956), campaign files (1954, 1960, 1966), public information files, post office appointments (1955-1965), Detroit office files (1955-1966), memorabilia (1942-1966), and government publications. The subject files include general correspondence, public relations and publicity materials, political affairs and activities, departmental files and general topical files on civil rights, Detroit, foreign relations, Michigan, and unions. Legislative files include correspondence on various issues including aging, agriculture, atomic energy, civil rights, education, irrigation, repeal of section 14b of the Taft-Hartley Act, taxes, and Vietnam. Committee files document work on the Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field and the Public Works Committee. Public information files include press releases, rough and final drafts of speeches, newspaper columns, radio addresses, and newsletters. Memorabilia includes scrapbooks (1942-1966), plaques, certificates, photographs, records, tapes, films, and mementos. Finding aid.

Correspondence in Detroit Council of Churches records, 1920-1969; International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace, and Agricultural Workers of America, Legislative Department records, 1943-1962; Wayne County AFL-CIO records of president and vice president, 1951-1967; and Michigan AFL-CIO Lansing office collection, 1930-1963.
Correspondence in John E. Fogarty papers, 1939-1967. Finding aid.
